content:
=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐language breakdown of the game’s design and a sample strategy:

• Genre & Style:
 – The game is a tile‐based puzzle/platformer with action and exploration elements. You control a character (the “avatar”) equipped with a weapon (named “sword” even though it uses a pickaxe image) and must navigate a level filled with obstacles, terrain (like dirt and walls), moving boulders, and various enemies.

• Game Mechanics:
 – Movement occurs on a grid-like level layout in which you interact with stationary elements (walls, dirt) and moving objects (boulders, enemy sprites such as a “crab” or “butterfly”).
 – Your tool/sword can be used to “kill” or remove certain sprites – for example, when it interacts with dirt, it appears to clear or “kill” that block.
 – Collectibles include diamonds scattered throughout the level. Picking these up increases your score (and probably counts toward your goal).
 – Some objects have physics-like behavior: For instance, boulders move (fall) and interacting with them from certain angles (like being hit from above) can either hurt you or, if used correctly, remove threats.
 – Enemies move around (like the random “enemy” and more specific creatures such as crabs and butterflies) and have special interactions with one another. For example, there is a rule where a crab and a butterfly interact, sometimes turning one into a collectible diamond if the interaction happens in the right order.

• Primary Objective:
 – You must collect resources (diamonds) from around the level. There is a requirement tied to exiting: When you reach the exit door, the door’s interaction checks the number of diamonds you’re holding, and only if you have a high enough count (usually 10 or more diamonds based on “limit=9” in the rule) does the door “activate” (in this case, it’s removed, triggering the win condition).
 – In summary, your aim is to explore the level, gather a sufficient amount of diamonds, and then head for the exit door to complete the level.

• Win/Loss Conditions:
 – Loss: If your avatar is eliminated (for example, by being crushed by a boulder or killed by an enemy), the avatar count falls to zero, and you lose.
 – Win: Achieved when the exit door is “killed” (or removed) from the level – which happens when you interact with it while having collected enough diamonds (the door’s rule “killIfOtherHasMore resource=diamond limit=9” suggests it only opens for you if you have more than nine diamonds).

• Overall Strategy:
 – Explore the level carefully. Look for diamonds and pathways while keeping an eye on obstacles like walls and dirt that you might need to remove.
 – Use your sword/weapon to clear paths, break up dirt, or even dispatch minor obstacles so you can access new areas.
 – Be mindful of boulders: they move slowly downward and can either be used to your advantage (for example, knocking enemies out) or can hurt you if you’re caught under one. Try to maneuver so you only interact with boulders from above when necessary.
 – Watch enemy behavior. Some enemies (like the enemy sprite or the crab and butterfly pair) have interactions that might even turn one into diamonds if used properly. Knowing these mechanics can help you turn threats into rewards.
 – Once you’ve collected enough diamonds (aim for at least 10), search for the green exit door. When you get there, make sure you have met the diamond requirement so that interacting with the door results in a win.
 – Stay constantly aware of your surroundings, and plan your moves to prevent being cornered or trapped by enemies and falling boulders.

In essence, balance careful exploration and puzzle-solving (clearing obstacles and gathering diamonds) with quick, reactive maneuvers to avoid or manipulate dangerous elements. This mix of strategic resource collection and platforming challenges makes for a dynamic and engaging gameplay experience.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.

Action:5

I'm rotating upward to face the boulder above at (6,23) so that I can use my boulder sword next to reposition it and clear a passage.

background dirt -> '.'

boulder sword -> 'w'

===Long-term Plan===
```**sword strategy: Employ the sword to target and eliminate obstructive butterflies that may be impeding progress in this narrow corridor; subsequently, batch-process nearby background dirt to uncover a clear, uninterrupted path toward the exit door—and if persistent obstructions block advancement, immediately reassign priority to boulder repositioning with Alert** with **Alert**```

Action:4

I'm moving downward from (7,23) to (8,23) along the cleared corridor toward the exit door, expecting to encounter and clear any obstructive dirt or butterflies in subsequent steps as planned.
